paragraphs.text: Architects supply ideas and drawings to make a building, but where do physical building materials come from? Each building material or component is the product of a journey that includes processes of extraction, manufacturing, finishing, and assembly, often combining local and global networks.

sections.title: Concrete
paragraphs: Beneath their hand-placed brick and stone façades, Franklin and Murray Colleges have modern structural frames of reinforced concrete and steel. Concrete is an ancient material—in its most basic form a mixture of crushed stone or gravel, cement, and water—but in recent decades it has become stronger and more durable through technological refinements. Reinforcing steel bar (“rebar”) is also an essential component of modern structural concrete.

The mixing plant is located in New Haven, but the constituent ingredients of the concrete can be traced to quarries and factories in the region. The heaviest and most voluminous ingredient is crushed rock or aggregate (about 17,000 tons), which is quarried just 20 miles from the building site in Meriden, Connecticut. This igneous “trap rock” or basalt, formed by geological processes millions of years ago, is favored for its density and strength. The next biggest ingredient by volume is sand (about 12,000 tons), which is really just rock that has been broken by water into fine grains. The sand comes from a supplier in Cape Cod, Massachusetts, and is perhaps the only ingredient to be transported to New Haven by barge.

Concrete is a relatively local material. Its journey to the building site at Yale was shorter than that of many other materials, reflecting its large mass and cost to transport, as well as the huge quantities needed: over 33,000 cubic yards of ready-mix, weighing in at over 60,000 tons, to be poured into the forms of columns and slabs reinforced internally by rebar.

Cement (4,500 tons)—the glue that holds all the rock together—is trucked in from a factory in the Hudson Valley. Water is necessary to activate the chemical binding properties of the cement; about 4,500 tons of fresh water was added to the mix, courtesy of the municipal water system headquartered at the Whitney Water Center. All the structural concrete of the new residential colleges is reinforced with steel bar, unlike some of Yale’s 1930s residential colleges that rest on unreinforced concrete foundation walls.

The rebar used in the new construction, estimated to weigh 3,200 tons, is manufactured in Connecticut from recycled steel. It would be interesting to map the previous life and journeys of this recycled steel, but the data were not available at the time of research. The market for recycled steel appears to include mills from around the country and even beyond national borders.
